templateAssets.content:
The BA in Criminal Justice is an approved match to:

  • Administration of Justice (AS-T)
  • Law, Public Policy, and Society (AA-T)

attributes.content: Recommended; Not required for the major

course.courseTitle: Social Welfare Institutions: A Response to Power and Scarcity

templateAssets.content: In sections below where the student is directed to select courses and there is a note "Only lower division courses listed," upper division courses are also available. See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements.

• See the University Catalog for the full listing of degree requirements for this major.
  • See the Admissions website for transfer admission requirements/information.
  • See the International Education & Global Engagement website for international transfer academic qualifications.
  • See the Academic Advising Programs website for information on California Promise and Associate Degree for Transfer.
  • See the University Catalog for Credit by Exam information (AP, IB, CLEP).

General Education courses are recommended, but not required, to support the student in this major.

  • See Group 1: Recommended General Education Courses, for the selection of the following GE Mathematical Concepts and Quantitative Reasoning (2) courses.

In the Criminal Justice Disciplinary Electives area (Group 3).

  • Note that a minimum of 7 courses from subjects CRIM, INTR, LEGL, PADM, and POLS must be included in the "Select 11 of the following."

This agreement is not a static document. Articulations may be updated or added at any time, and the information provided is subject to change without notice.


This agreement does not include upper-division major requirements, course prerequisites, general education coursework, or university-specific graduation requirements necessary for degree completion.


Department agreements should be referenced alongside major agreements to ensure a clearer understanding of course articulation and program planning.

course.courseTitle: Social Welfare Institutions: A Response to Power and Scarcity
